title: Gent-Wevelgem 2023: Route, riders, TV and all you need to know
content:
Cyclist
Gent-Wevelgem 2023: Route, riders, TV and all you need to know

Despite its name, the one day Gent-Wevelgem classic no longer starts in Gent, but at the Menin Gate in Ypres, commemorating the First World War. The official name of the race also references the Great War: ‘Gent Wevelgem – In Flanders Fields’. The men’s race covers 260.9km, the women’s race 162.5km.

Taking place a week before the Tour of Flanders on Sunday 26th March, the race has a different character to De Ronde due to the comparative paucity of cobbled climbs, the last of which is the Kemmelberg, the highest point in West Flanders, tackled from two directions both with gradients up to 20%. The men’s race – but not the women’s – also includes three sections of unpaved ‘plugstreets’ over 10km.

The weather can make the difference too; much of the early racing is on flat, exposed roads towards the Belgian coast, with the climbs starting 166km into the men’s race and 98km into the women’s race. Crosswinds can break up the field and in 2015 they were fierce enough to result in riders being blown into ditches and only 39 finishing.

The women’s race climbs the Kemmelberg twice in its total of seven climbs while the men’s race takes it in three times in its total of nine climbs. In both cases the final ascent is some 34km from the finish line, making it potentially decisive in the final selection, but often allowing the sprinters to regroup and contest the win.

That’s highlighted by the list of winners below. Last year’s men’s race saw the breakout victory of Eritrean star Biniam Girmay, who went on to win a stage of the 2022 Giro d’Italia before promptly dropping out after popping a prosecco cork into his eye. This year, he’s already won Stage 1 of the Volta a la Comunitat Valenciana. The 2022 women’s race was won from a chaotic sprint by Elisa Balsamo in the rainbow jersey.

The inaugural men’s race was back in 1934, with a Who’s Who of the great Classics riders having won over the years. The women’s race joined the men’s race in 2012, with Lizzie Deignan the first winner. As with all races promoted by Flanders Classics, there is now equal prize money for the men’s and women’s races.

Gent-Wevelgem 2023: Key information

Date: Sunday 26th March 2023
Start: Ypres/Ieper, Belgium
Finish: Wevelgem, Belgium
Distance: Men’s 260.9km; Women’s 162.5km
Major climbs: Men’s 9; Women’s 7
UK television coverage: Eurosport, GCN+, Discovery+

Gent-Wevelgem 2023: How to watch

Gent-Wevelgem will be broadcast live on Eurosport and available to stream live on GCN+ and Discovery+ (all with the same coverage, times below).

GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year and Discovery+ costs £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like 90 Day Fiancé and Ghost Adventures).

Streaming coverage via GCN+ will be available in Europe and the Asia-Pacific, not including Australia, China and New Zealand, double-check territory restrictions to avoid disappointment.

In the Australia, Canada and the United States there’s live coverage of the race FloBikes, and in New Zealand it’s on Sky.

Men’s race: 12:00-16:40 live coverage on Eurosport, GCN+ and Discovery+
Women’s race: 15:15-17:50 live coverage on Eurosport, GCN+ and Discovery+
Times GMT and subject to change by broadcaster

Gent-Wevelgem 2023 men’s route and profile

As you can see Gent-Wevelgem is a purely West Flanders race, hugging the French border for most of the route

The cluster of climbs and long flat tarmac section following the last one is why this race tends to be won by sprinters.

Gent-Wevelgem 2023 women’s route and profile

Although it’s a warm-up for the Tour of Flanders the following week, Wevelgem is actually only 25km from Roubaix, closer than all the famous bergs of the Ronde.

The women’s race has even fewer climbs than the men’s, and with the best sprinters in the women’s peloton also being adept uphill it won’t be an easy task for a break to stay away.
